docs.snippet: Car thieves, beware: increasingly concerned by high theft rates and escalating insurance premiums on their cars, auto makers are putting new and more potent weapons in their defensive arsenal. Realizing the futility of car alarms that are often ig...
docs.abstract: Auto makers, increasingly concerned about high auto theft rates and escalating insurance premiums on their cars, are installing devices that immobilize car unless correct key is used (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Car thieves, beware: increasingly concerned by high theft rates and escalating insurance premiums on their cars, auto makers are putting new and more potent weapons in their defensive arsenal. Realizing the futility of car alarms that are often ignored, the companies are installing devices that immobilize the car unless the correct key is used. These devices give owners special keys with tiny transmitters that send a numerical code that constantly changes. Once the key is inserted into the ignition, a sensor determines whether the code matches one of the billions stored in the car's memory. If the code is not recognized, the car will not start. Because the key sends a different code every time, thieves find it almost impossible to decipher them.

headline.main: A Warning to Thieves: Right Key Is Needed

docs.snippet: The New York Times on the Web, the World Wide Web service of The New York Times, won 2 of the 10 prizes awarded by Editor and Publisher magazine last week, one for best overall on-line newspaper service and one for best editorial content by an on-...
docs.abstract: New York Times on the Web, the World Wide Web service of The New York Times, won 2 of 10 prizes awarded by Editor and Publisher magazine last week, one for best overall on-line newspaper service and one for best editorial content by an on-line newspaper service; other winners noted (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The New York Times on the Web, the World Wide Web service of The New York Times, won 2 of the 10 prizes awarded by Editor and Publisher magazine last week, one for best overall on-line newspaper service and one for best editorial content by an on-line newspaper service. The Times won among daily papers with a circulation of more than 100,000. The Sun Herald of Port Charlotte, Fla., won the award for best overall on-line newspaper service for dailies under 100,000 circulation. The editorial-content award went to Florida Today Space Online of Melbourne, Fla., a Gannett property.

headline.main: Times Site On the Web Wins Awards

docs.snippet: IN today's escalating struggle for control of the nation's communications networks, the Federal Communications Commission is where the battle between commercial and public interest rages visibly -- and where the winners can be different one day to...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN today's escalating struggle for control of the nation's communications networks, the Federal Communications Commission is where the battle between commercial and public interest rages visibly -- and where the winners can be different one day to the next. For example, the F.C.C. lost a big chunk of influence last week when a three-judge Federal panel in Philadelphia resoundingly rejected as unconstitutional the Communications Decency Act, which was intended to ban so-called indecent speech on the Internet. The F.C.C. had been designated as the C.D.A. police.

headline.main: Debate over advanced TV gives the F.C.C. a chance to be assertive.

docs.snippet: Knight-Ridder Inc. has decided that it is not interested in buying The Star Tribune of Minneapolis, the company's chairman and chief executive said.    The Star Tribune's parent, Cowles Media, said on Thursday that it was exploring a possible merg...
docs.abstract: Knight-Ridder Inc decides that it is not interested in buying Star Tribune of Minneapolis; Star Tribune's parent, Cowles Media, said on Sept 4 that it was exploring possible merger or sale of newspaper (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Knight-Ridder Inc. has decided that it is not interested in buying The Star Tribune of Minneapolis, the company's chairman and chief executive said. The Star Tribune's parent, Cowles Media, said on Thursday that it was exploring a possible merger or sale involving the newspaper, Minnesota's largest. Analysts say that a deal could be worth $1.3 billion.

headline.main: Knight-Ridder Decides One Twin City Is Enough

docs.snippet: Frank Shepherd, the president and chief executive of 21st Century Newspapers Inc., who recently bought The Oakland Press, will serve as publisher of the paper, which is based in Pontiac, Mich.    Mr. Shepherd, 55, succeeds Dale Duncan, who resigne...
docs.abstract: Frank Shepherd, president and chief executive of 21st Century Newspapers Inc, who recently bought The Oakland Press, will serve as publisher of paper, which is based in Pontiac, Mich; Shepherd succeeds Dale Duncan, who resigned last week (S)0
docs.lead_paragraph: Frank Shepherd, the president and chief executive of 21st Century Newspapers Inc., who recently bought The Oakland Press, will serve as publisher of the paper, which is based in Pontiac, Mich. Mr. Shepherd, 55, succeeds Dale Duncan, who resigned last week.

headline.main: President of Chain To Serve as Publisher Of Michigan Paper

docs.snippet: In a modest expansion of its staff, USA Today has hired a handful of additional reporters and editors with the object of helping the big nationwide daily, best known for the brevity of its stories, to expand coverage into longer and more investiga...
docs.abstract: USA Today hires few more reporters and editors in bid to expand coverage into longer and more investigative pieces; is opening bureaus in Denver, Atlanta and Boston; Linda Mathews, former New York Times national editor, is joining USA Today's national desk (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: In a modest expansion of its staff, USA Today has hired a handful of additional reporters and editors with the object of helping the big nationwide daily, best known for the brevity of its stories, to expand coverage into longer and more investigative pieces. The paper is opening bureaus in Denver, Atlanta and Boston, where previously it had relied on freelancers, and is adding a Life section reporter to the paper's San Francisco bureau, which now houses a financial writer, and two reporters to its national staff, Dave Mazzarella, the paper's editor, said.

headline.main: USA Today Is to Expand Editorial Staff

docs.snippet: The Walt Disney Company is close to a deal to acquire Mammoth Records, a small independent record company, for between $20 million and $25 million, a person familiar with the discussions said.    Disney is not alone in its interest in Mammoth, the...
docs.abstract: Walt Disney Co is close to deal to acquire Mammoth Records for between $20 million and $25 million; Mammoth's other suitors reportedly include Philips Electronics NV's Polygram unit and Michael P Schulhof; Mammoth's prime attraction to Disney is its owner, Jay Faires, who is regarded as up-and-coming executive who could fill Disney's music management void (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The Walt Disney Company is close to a deal to acquire Mammoth Records, a small independent record company, for between $20 million and $25 million, a person familiar with the discussions said. Disney is not alone in its interest in Mammoth, the person said. Other bidders are said to include Polygram, a unit of Philips ElectronicsN.V., and Michael P. Schulhof, the former president of the Sony Corporation of America. Neither Disney nor the other reported bidders could be reached for comment yesterday.

headline.main: Disney Is Said To Pursue A Music Label

docs.snippet: The Intel Corporation is raising the bar again.    The world's largest maker of computer chips is about to introduce its latest microprocessor, the Pentium II. The processor, running at speeds of up to 300 megahertz and sporting a unique cartridge...
docs.abstract: Intel Corp, world's largest maker of computer chips, will introduce its latest microprocessor, the Pentium II, running at speeds of up to 300 megahertz and sporting unique cartridge design (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The Intel Corporation is raising the bar again. The world's largest maker of computer chips is about to introduce its latest microprocessor, the Pentium II. The processor, running at speeds of up to 300 megahertz and sporting a unique cartridge design, is Intel's latest attempt to extend its most advanced technology into the mainstream.

docs.snippet: Amy Gross, the editor in chief of Mirabella magazine for the last two years, resigned abruptly last week. A spokesman for Hachette Filipacchi Magazines said there were ''creative differences'' and refused to give further details.     Ms. Gross, wh...
docs.abstract: Amy Gross resigns as editor in chief of Mirabella magazine after two years (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Amy Gross, the editor in chief of Mirabella magazine for the last two years, resigned abruptly last week. A spokesman for Hachette Filipacchi Magazines said there were ''creative differences'' and refused to give further details. Ms. Gross, who did not respond to a request for comment, had worked at Hachette's Elle magazine as editorial director since 1993. When the company acquired Mirabella from the News Corporation in 1995, she took the helm of Mirabella as well, stepping down from Elle last October. Ms. Gross had been the magazine's top editor under its founder, Grace Mirabella, from 1989 to 1993, when she left for Elle, then a competitor.

docs.snippet: WITH on-line and interactive media businesses across the country scrabbling to stay in business, the bells and whistles of multimedia on the Internet may well be covering the groans of those who have discovered the realities of digital commerce.  ...
docs.abstract: Denise Caruso article questions value of adding digital video windows to World Wide Web sites; discusses Progressive Networks Inc's plan to offer product that delivers video and other media to computers via Internet in transmission stream that approximates instant playback (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: WITH on-line and interactive media businesses across the country scrabbling to stay in business, the bells and whistles of multimedia on the Internet may well be covering the groans of those who have discovered the realities of digital commerce. Increasingly, for example, media companies on the World Wide Web are providing site visitors with 2-by-3-inch windows of jerky digital video that have been snipped from films or television broadcasts -- a science-fair application of technology that seems superfluous even when everything works as planned, which it almost never does.

headline.main: The puzzle of making the Internet into a competitive broadcast medium.
